reference.shortdesc: The responsibleParty element identifies the individual or team whose task it is to perform a remedy procedure.

section.title: Specialization hierarchy
section.p: The responsibleParty element is specialized from p. It is defined in the troubleshooting module.

draft-comment.author: Kristen James Eberlein
draft-comment.p: Why is this specialized from p? I know that we included the element because it was part of the IBM troublehooting specialization, but I think it should be specialized from data, so it is not rendered by default. It's metadata that implementations might use to generate some text, but I can't imagine that anyone wants it rendered by default.

div.p: Dawn: All my clients who use it do want it rendered, if that counts for anything. They want readers of the content to understand that there are some things they should not attempt on their own – they don't have the right permissions, it voids their warranty, etc. We tend to implement special formatting on it – making it look like a note or similar to call attention to the restriction at the beginning of the remedy section.

@Dawn, I'm sure that your clients want something rendered from the responsibleParty element. But, do they ever render just the contents of the element? Or are they using the element to contain more than the name of the responsible party?
Given the example in this topic, if it was rendered as-is, there would just be the following preceding the steps:
Can you provide some examples of what your clients put n ths element?

I wonder if we should redesign this element, if it is intended to be rendered. New name, new definition, new examples. In particular, maybe we should broaden the element to not just include the name of the "responsible party," but also any needed warnings or notes ...

example.title: Example
example.p: In the following code sample, the responsibleParty element indicates the person who should perform the task:
example.codeblock: <remedy> <title>Remedy</title> <responsibleParty>IT technical support</responsibleParty> <steps> <step><cmd>Turn the system power switch to <hwcontrol>Off</hwcontrol>.</cmd></step> <step><cmd>Reset the circuit breaker.</cmd></step> <step><cmd>Turn the system power switch to <hwcontrol>On</hwcontrol>.</cmd></step> </steps> </remedy>
